exam.source: National Center For University Entrance Examination
exam.subject: SekaishiB(main exam)

exam:
Center-1997--Main-WorldHistoryB
1997 Academic Year Main Examination: World History B
[1]
Read the following texts A-C, which relate to war and peace in the 20th century, and answer the questions (Questions 1-11) below.
(33 points)
ＡIn terms of characteristics of the First World War, firstly, (1)many new weapons appeared, which increased the scale of the human and physical damage.Secondly, the war became prolonged, turning into total war, in which the main participants mobilized their human, economic, and scientific might.Consequently, (2)even citizens who did not set foot on the battlefield suffered the effects of war in various ways, and the understanding and cooperation of the populace became essential to the conduct of the war.Thirdly, (3)many countries not only in Europe, but also in Asia, Africa, and America became involved in the war for various reasons, so it truly was a world war, as the name suggests.In addition, during the Second World War, the aforementioned characteristics were amplified further.
Question 1
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that contains a mistake in regard to the underlined portion (1).
１
①Poison gas was used in trench warfare.
②Tanks were developed in order to break through the trenches.
③Aircraft were used for reconnaissance and bombing.
④Unrestricted submarine warfare was carried out by the United States of America.
Question 2
In regard to the underlined portion (2), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence concerning the situation relating to the main European participants in the war that contains a mistake.
２
①Immediately after the outbreak of war, the socialist political parties in each country simultaneously launched an antiwar movement.
②Production and distribution of consumer goods stagnated, and food shortages and price rises occurred in some countries.
③In some countries, women were employed in the production of weapons at munitions factories.
④Feelings of war-weariness spread among the people, and there were countries in which this developed into revolution.
Question 3
In regard to the underlined portion (3), from ①~④ below, choose the one correct option that is the name of a country that participated in the war on the allied side.
３
①Switzerland
②Italy
③Belgium
④Bulgaria
Question 4
In regard again to the underlined portion (3), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes Asian countries during or after the First World War.
４
①India was a French colony, so it had to dispatch many soldiers to the battlefields of Europe.
②Japan participated in the war on the basis of the Anglo-Japanese Alliance and occupied Qingdao in Shandong Province.
③The UK promised independence to the Arabs under the Balfour Declaration.
④In China after the war, a reform and self-strengthening movement (reform movement) arose in opposition to the Treaty of Versailles.
ＢThe world economy, which had been afflicted by exhaustion and confusion due to the First World War, began to show signs of recovery in the latter half of the 1920s, and it was thought that it might recover its pre-war dynamism.However, triggered by the October 1929 stock price crash on the (4) stock exchange, (5)capitalist countries were beset by a prolonged recession and social instability spread.On the other hand, during this period, the Soviet Union kept its distance from the capitalist world and progressed along the path to becoming an independent industrial state.
Question 5
From ①~④ below, choose the most appropriate city name that should be inserted into the gap marked (4) in the text.
５
①London
②Paris
③Berlin
④New York
Question 6
In regard to the underlined portion (5), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes events during the 1930s.
６
①In the UK, MacDonald put together a national unity government.
②In Germany, Hitler came to power and withdrew from the League of Nations.
③In Italy, Mussolini established a fascist regime.
④In the United States of America, Franklin Roosevelt implemented the New Deal policy.
Question 7
The graph below shows changes in the proportion accounted for by each country in the total value of industrial production in four countries, during the period from before the First World War to before the Second World War.From ①~④ below, choose the correct combination of country names that correspond to letters a-d.(Please note that the figure for the Soviet Union in 1913 is actually for Imperial Russia.)
７
①aSoviet UnionbGermany cUnited KingdomdUnited States of America
②aGermanybSoviet Union cUnited States of AmericadUnited Kingdom
③aSoviet UnionbUnited Kingdom cUnited States of AmericadGermany
④aUnited KingdombUnited States of America cGermanydSoviet Union
ＣAfter the end of the Second World War, which had brought about unprecedented damage, people hoped that such tragedy would never be repeated.The concept of an organization to maintain peace had already been discussed during the war, and the (6)United Nations was officially established in 1945.However, (7)a Cold War began between the US and the Soviet Union, and the world faced another serious conflict.In relation to this, (8)movements emerged that criticized the current situation, which was focused on conventional military might and violence, and emphasized peaceful means instead.Moreover, in order to create peace, not only military factors, but also (9)complex problems such as economic factor came to be considered.
Question 8
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (6).
８
①The policy of establishing an organization for peace was set forth in 1941 in the Atlantic Charter.
②The nations vanquished in the Second World War also acceded to the United Nations from the outset.
③The People's Republic of China has been a permanent member of the Security Council since that body's establishment.
④The Korean War ended within a year, due to the intervention of United Nations forces.
Question 9
In regard to the underlined portion (7), from ①~④ below, choose the correct chronological sequence of events relating to the Cold War.
９
①Warsaw Treaty Organization formed - Berlin blockade - Cuban missile crisis - Japan-US Security Treaty signed (1951)
②Berlin blockade - Japan-US Security Treaty signed (1951) - Warsaw Treaty Organization formed - Cuban missile crisis
③Japan-US Security Treaty signed (1951) - Cuban missile crisis - Berlin blockade - Warsaw Treaty Organization formed
④Berlin blockade - Warsaw Treaty Organization formed - Japan-US Security Treaty signed (1951) - Cuban missile crisis
Question 10
In regard to the underlined portion (8), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence in which the wavy line is incorrect.
10
①At the 1961 Conference of Heads of State or Government of Non-Aligned Countries, participants called for peaceful coexistence and anticolonialism.
②Zhou Enlai and Nehru announced the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence and formulated new guidelines concerning international relations.
③Under the Locarno Treaties, arrangements were made concerning the security of the North Atlantic.
④In the United States of America, a movement focused on the elimination of racial discrimination by nonviolent means developed around Pastor King.
Question 11
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (9).
11
①The European Economic Community (EEC) promoted economic integration focused on the UK.
②The North-South divide is a term that indicates the differences between the United States of America and the Soviet Union in terms of their political and economic systems.
③The oil crises (Oil Shock) occurred because of a reduction in the price of crude oil and oversupply by the Arab oil-producing countries.
④Asia saw the emergence of the newly-industrializing economies (NIES), which achieved rapid economic growth.
[2]
Read the following texts A-C, which relate to inscriptions on monuments, paintings, and relics throughout world history, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(21 points)
ＡMankind depicted the spiritual world in paintings, but when written characters were eventually developed, humanity acquired a means of communicating things more accurately and more broadly.Initially, characters were mainly used by people in the ruling class.They (1)inscribed royal edicts on stone pillars, and (2)carved the genealogy of royal families and the achievements of kings onto immense stones, to convey this information to future generations.At the same time, one can see the nature of diplomatic correspondence on (3)stone steles on which the promises made between states were carved.Along with clay tablets and bamboo and wooden slips, these are prized as historical sources from the period concerned.
Question 1
In regard to the underlined portion (1), Photograph (a) is a stone pillar on which the royal edict of an ancient Indian king has been carved.Choose the correct explanation from ①~④ below.
12
①It is the pillar that proclaims eternal rule over northeastern India, which Alexander the Great conquered.
②It is the pillar on which Chandragupta announced to the nation his policy of enriching the country and strengthening the military after unifying southern India.
③It is the pillar on which Ashoka, having converted to Buddhism, announced to the nation his policy of rule based on dharma.
④It is the pillar on which Kanishka ordered the protection of Hinduism in northwestern India, which he had conquered.
Question 2
In regard to the underlined portion (2), the Gwanggaeto Stele of Goguryeo records developments in East Asia at the end of the 4th century.From ①~④ below, choose the correct option showing the name of a country that appears therein.
13
①Eastern Han
②Wei
③Sui
④Baekje
Question 3
The Tang-Tubo Alliance Monument, which commemorates peace between the Tang and the Tibetan Empire, is an example of the monuments referred to in the underlined portion (3).In relation to this, from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the Tibetan Empire.
14
①The Tibetan Empire primarily flourished in northern Vietnam.
②The Tibetan alphabet was created in the Tibetan Empire.
③Islamic culture and Chinese culture were merged in the Tibetan Empire.
④The Tibetan Empire fell after being attacked by Kublai Khan.
BRelics such as stones and ceramics bearing characters, which have been found in the Orient and Greece hitherto, are extremely precious historical sources for learning about the society of the times.The stone slab shown in (a) below, which was discovered by chance in 1799 at Rosetta, at the mouth of the Nile, is called the (4)Rosetta Stone, and is currently displayed at the British Museum.The upper part of the stone stele shown in (b) below, which was discovered at Susa in 1901, features a relief carving that depicts the king receiving the (5)code of laws from Shamash, the god of justice, and below this are carved the preamble, the provisions of 282 articles, and the epilogue.On the other hand, the numerous ostraca (potsherds) discovered in the agora on the north side of the Acropolis in Athens differ somewhat in purpose from the aforementioned two examples.The potsherd shown in (c) below was written on by a citizen of Athens in the 5th century BCE, and is probably an (6)ostracon, used in the system of ostrakismos (ostracism).
Question 4
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (4).
15
①In order, starting from the top, this stone slab is inscribed with hieroglyphs, Demotic characters, and Greek characters.
②In order, starting from the top, this stone slab is inscribed with Persian characters, Aramaic characters, and Phoenician characters
③The inscriptions on this stone slab convey a decree from Syria at the time of the Seleucid Empire.
④The inscriptions on this stone slab convey a decree from Macedonia at the time of the Antigonid dynasty.
Question 5
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that contains a mistake in regard to the underlined portion (5).
16
①This code of laws is inscribed in cuneiform script.
②This code of laws includes the principle of exact reciprocity.
③This code of laws is called the Code of Hammurabi, after the king who promulgated it.
④The kingdom that used this code of laws was overthrown by the Akkadians
Question 6
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (6).
17
①The citizens of Athens cast these potsherds in order to select members of their council.
②The citizens of Athens cast these potsherds in order to select their consuls and generals.
③The citizens of Athens voted by writing the name of the faction that they endorsed on these potsherds.
④The citizens of Athens voted by writing the name of the person whom they feared might become a tyrant on these potsherds.
ＣThe following photographs (a)-(c) show famous pictures and ruins.
Question 7
From ①~④ below, choose the option that is most appropriate as an explanation of the picture in photograph (a).
18
①It depicts an expedition by the pharaoh.
②It depicts a dead person being judged by a god.
③It depicts the solar calendar used in Egypt.
④It depicts the marriage ceremony of a pharaoh and his queen during the New Kingdom period
Question 8
From ①~④ below, choose the option that is most appropriate as an explanation of the ruin in photograph (b).
19
①This is called Angkor Wat and was a Hindu temple.
②This is called Angkor Wat and was a Muslim temple.
③This is called Borobudur and was a Hindu temple.
④This is called Borobudur and was a Muslim temple.
Question 9
From ①~④ below, choose the option that is most appropriate as an explanation of the ruin in photograph (c).
20
①It is an annex to the mausoleum of Qin Shihuangdi, the First Emperor.
②It is an annex to the mausoleum of the king of Nanyue.
③It is an annex to the mausoleum of Emperor Wu of Han.
④It is an annex to the mausoleum of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang.
[3]
Read the following texts A-C, which relate to social status and class throughout world history, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(20 points)
ＡThere is a view that, from the Song period to the Qing period, the ruling class in Chinese society was the class of scholar-officials.They were distinct from the common people by the fact that they were generally landowners and were well-versed in learning, particularly the Confucian classics.(1)The cultural pursuits in which they engaged also differed from those of the common people.(2)Some scholar-officials became government officials through Imperial examinations, and ruled the common people as proxies of the emperor.However, the distinction between the two classes was not fixed, and the path to joining the class of scholar-officials was open to high-caliber people if they passed the Imperial examinations, even if they were the children of common people.The fact that a certain degree of fluidity between the classes existed is accepted to have been one factor that contributed to the stability of Chinese society.
Question 1
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that contains a mistake in regard to the underlined portion (1).
21
①Romance of the Three Kingdoms is a leading work of popular literature.
②During the Yuan period, many plays such as The Story of the Western Wing were written, and were loved by the common people.
③During the Ming period, Yangmingism became the state-sanctioned approach to learning, forming the basis of the thinking and action of scholar-officials.
④During the Qing dynasty, many scholar-officials were mobilized in the compilation of works such as the Siku Quanshu (The Complete Library in the Four Branches of Literature).
Question 2
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence regarding the underlined portion (2) in which the part with the wavy line is correct.
22
①The palace examination, which was the final stage of the Imperial examinations, was conducted in the palace, with the prime minister serving as the examiner.
②Under the Yuan dynasty, which adopted a policy of putting the Semu caste first, Imperial examinations were hardly ever held and the path to becoming a government official was effectively closed to scholar-officials.
③Under the Ming dynasty, the Imperial examination system was upgraded and scholar-officials were employed as government officials, but in addition to the emergence of factions among the government officials, the influence of the eunuchs grew, thereby disrupting government.
④During the Westernization movement under the Qing dynasty, large-scale reforms of the bureaucratic system were carried out, the Imperial examinations were abolished, and graduates of the new schools were employed as government officials.
ＢIn the Muslim world, it was a tenet that all people were equal under Allah, the one and only god, and that the Prophet Muhammad was also just a human, so there was no clergy as there was in Christianity and Buddhism.Even in situations relating to political rule, the fundamental principle was of governance based on Islam, which transcended ethnic differences, as seen from the fact that regimes ruled by Iranian, (3)Turkic, Mongol, Berber, and (4)black rulers emerged in various parts of the Muslim world.There was a legal distinction between free people and non-free people (slaves), but having slave lineage was not in itself a problem in terms of qualification to become a ruler, as seen from the fact that the (5)Mamluks, who had been slaves, were accepted as rulers.Occupations were not restricted on the basis of status: both soldiers and government officials engaged in commerce, and a separate social status for merchants and artisan craftsmen was not formed.(6), who pursued various Islamic studies, such as jurisprudence, were active as teachers, religious leaders, judges, and government officials, fulfilling a role in unifying society.
Question 3
In regard to the underlined portion (3), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence concerning the movement of the Turks of Central Asia that contains a mistake.
23
①The Göktürks overthrew the Mongol Rouran Khaganate.
②The Göktürks split into east and west factions in the 6th century.
③The Uyghur dispatched reinforcements in order to quell the An Lushan Rebellion.
④The Uyghur adopted Islam as their state religion at the time of their founding.
Question 4
In regard to the underlined portion (4), the following map shows the states led by black people that were created in Africa.From ①~④ below, choose the correct arrangement of country names that correspond to the areas marked (a) - (c) in the diagram.
24
①aGhana EmpirebKingdom of MutapacKingdom of Kush
②aGhana EmpirebKingdom of KushcKingdom of Mutapa
③aKingdom of MutapabKingdom of KushcGhana Empire
④aKingdom of MutapabGhana EmpirecKingdom of Kush
Question 5
In regard to the underlined portion (5), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence concerning the Mamluks that contains a mistake.
25
①The Ghaznavids had Mamluk ancestry.
②The Almoravid dynasty was established by the Mamluks.
③The Ayyubid dynasty was overthrown in a coup d'état by the Mamluks.
④The Abbasid Caliphate employed the Mamluks as soldiers.
Question 6
From ①~④ below, choose the correct word that should be inserted into the gap marked (6) in the text.
26
①Ulama
②Sultans
③Brahmin
④Sufis
ＣFrom times of antiquity to the 18th-19th centuries, European societies were status-based societies.In the Greek and Roman worlds, the basic statuses were citizen and slave.(7)Among the Roman citizens there were aristocratic groups, such as the senators, but status and class differences were not fixed among the citizens.During the Middle Ages, a concept spread that focused on forming a society in which the three social orders of "those who pray, those who fight and those who work" helped each other out.(8)During the 12th-13th centuries, when burghs (autonomous towns) were established, citizen classes were formed that focused on merchants and artisan craftsmen.From the end of the Middle Ages through to the early modern period, some wealthy citizens were able to increase their social standing by purchasing aristocratic status.However, the system of social status that had been in place since the Middle Ages was maintained, even during the period of absolutism, and it was not dismantled until the (9)various popular revolutions and reforms of the 19th century.
Question 7
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that contains a mistake in regard to the underlined portion (7).
27
①Aristocrats, who were mainly major landowners, were called patricians.
②The post of Consul was monopolized by the aristocracy before Lex Licinia Sextia.
③Pompey, who came into conflict with the senate, governed jointly with Octavian.
④The Principate nominally respected the traditions of the republic, such as the senate.
Question 8
In regard to the underlined portion (8), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence concerning medieval cities that contains a mistake.
28
①Developed medieval cities were surrounded by defensive walls.
②In medieval cities, merchants and artisan craftsmen belonged to guilds, as a general rule.
③Augsburg flourished because of the silver produced in southern Germany.
④The cities of Flanders flourished because of the cotton industry.
Question 9
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (9).
29
①In France in 1789, peasants were emancipated from feudal tribute, for which they received no compensation.
②In Austria, Stein and Hardenberg emancipated the peasants.
③In Russia, social modernization was pursued through such means as the Emancipation Reform introduced by Alexander II.
④In the UK, aristocratic status was abolished by means of the Test Acts in the first half of the 19th century.
[4]
The following texts A-D are extracts from certain books.(Some have been rewritten or abridged.)Read the texts and answer the questions (Questions 1-11) below.
(26 points)
ＡThe following text is an extract from Donald Keene's Travelers of a Hundred Ages: The Japanese As Revealed Through 1,000 Years of Diaries (Part II), concerning the literature of travel written by Japanese travelers to China in the latter half of the 19th century.
(During the Meiji period) ships carrying missions to Europe frequently called at Shanghai.Among the members of the missions were quite a few people who recorded in their diaries their impressions of a country that seemed much more familiar to Japanese people than any of the countries of Europe.Nevertheless, there were cases in which these travelers were shocked and perplexed by the huge discrepancy between the reality and their mental image of China, formed by reading the (1)history and philosophy written several centuries earlier.Among the Japanese people who kept a diary of their visit to China was Takezoe Shin'ichiro *, whose work is often praised as a masterpiece of travel literature.San'un Kyou Nikki (A Diary of Clouds in the Mountain Pathways and Rain in the Ravines) depicts a journey that he made in 1876, (2)traveling from Beijing to Chongqing via Chengdu, and then down the Yangtze River to Shanghai.This journey took a total of 110 days.When in Beijing, Takezoe had been moved by the words of various travelers, who told of the beauty of the breathtaking (3)landscape of mountains and rivers in Sichuan Province.He developed a strong desire to see it for himself, whatever it took, and wrote at the very start of his diary, "I cannot suppress my yearning to travel".
*Takezoe Shin'ichiro (1842-1917) Confucian scholar from the Kumamoto Domain and Meiji government diplomat
Question 1
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (1).
30
①Sima Qian wrote about the history of the Western and Eastern Han periods in Records of the Grand Historian.
②Zhu Xi rejected distinctions between China and foreign lands, and between statuses, and advocated equality.
③Sima Guang compiled the Zizhi Tongjian (Comprehensive Mirror to Aid in Government), which is a chronological summary.
④Li Zhi (Li Zhuowu) handed down and developed the traditions of the Cheng-Zhu school.
Question 2
From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the cities referred to in the underlined portion (2).
31
①On the outskirts of Beijing is the Great Wall, which was repaired during the Ming period.
②Chengdu was the base for the Taiping Rebellion.
③The Tongmenghui (Chinese United League) was formed in Chongqing.
④The Nationalist government moved the capital city to Shanghai and fought against the Japanese army.
Question 3
In regard to the underlined portion (3), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence concerning landscape, nature, culture, and history that contains a mistake.
32
①The Shu state, one of the kingdoms during the Three Kingdoms period, was founded inland in Sichuan.
②Emperor Yang of Sui linked the Yellow River and the Yangtze River, which had different landscapes and cultures, by means of the Grand Canal.
③During the Yuan period, grain from the Jiangnan region was brought by canal to the capital city in northern China.
④Commercial cities such as Luoyang flourished in the lower reaches of the Yangtze River, where water transport was convenient.
ＢThe following text is an extract from Fukuo Jiden, the autobiography of Fukuzawa Yukichi.
It was the (4)first year of the Man'en era when I returned from the USA.However, in the winter of the first year of the Bunkyu era (the following year), an emissary was dispatched from Japan to Europe, and I had the opportunity to accompany him.At that time, (5) of France was being hailed as Europe's premier politician, but it was said that one should be on one's guard in relation to the neighboring country of Prussia, as this was a country in the ascendancy. (Upon visiting Europe) The easiest things for foreigners to understand, most of which are not even written in the dictionary, are the hardest things for us.I didn't understand the election laws in politics at all.Moreover, there were political parties, like factions, in the form of the Conservative party and the Liberal party, (6)who would engage in political fights in peace time.Someone would tell me that this person was the enemy of the other person, but I would see them eating and drinking at the same table. I don't understand it at all.
Question 4
In regard to the underlined portion (4), in this year, a candidate from the Republican Party was elected for the first time in a presidential election in the United States of America.From ①~④ below, choose the correct option showing the name of that figure.
33
①Jefferson
②Lincoln
③Wilson
④Carter
Question 5
From ①~④ below, choose the most appropriate name of a person that should be inserted into the gap marked (5) in the text.
34
①Lafayette
②Louis Philippe
③Napoleon III
④Clemenceau
Question 6
In regard to the underlined portion (6), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes political parties in the latter half of the 19th century.
35
①In the United States of America, slavery was abolished as a result of debate by the Republican Party and the Democratic Party in Congress.
②In the UK, the extension of the right to vote was hampered by conflict between the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party.
③In Germany, Cavour ran the country skilfully, while engaging in repeated bouts of conflict and compromise with Catholics and socialists.
④In France, the Dreyfus affair caused turmoil in the Republic.
ＣThe following text is an extract from Utopia, by the 16th-century British thinker Thomas More.
"But I do not think people steal only because of this; there is another cause of it, more peculiar to England."
"What is that?" said the Cardinal:
"The increase of pasture," said I, "(7)by which your sheep, which are naturally mild, and easily kept in order, may be said now to devour men and unpeople, not only villages, but towns……. the nobility and gentry, and even those holy men, the (8)abbots not contented with the old rents which their farms yielded, nor thinking it enough that they, living at their ease, do no good to the public, resolve to do it hurt instead of good."
Question 7
The underlined portion (7) is a metaphor for the enclosures being carried out in Britain at that time.From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes these enclosures.
36
①Landowners confiscated land from the peasants in order to engage in sheep farming, and enclosed it using hedges.
②Landowners used hedges to enclose land used for sheep farming, and turned it into agricultural land, on which they grew wheat.
③Landowners sought to charge high rents, so the peasants opposed this by using hedges to enclose land used for sheep farming.
④In order to make landowners increase food production, agricultural land was enclosed using hedges, and capitalist large-scale agricultural management was carried out.
Question 8
In regard to the underlined portion (8), from ①~④ below, choose the one sentence describing religious issues in Europe at that time, in which the word/phrase with a wavy line below is correct.
37
①In Germany, the conflict between the Catholics and the Lutherans intensified, but peace was established at Zurich in 1555.
②Henry VII carried out the Protestant Reformation in 1534, and built the foundations of the Church of England.
③Ignatius of Loyola formed the Society of Jesus in 1534, and sought to restore Catholic influence.
④Louis XIV issued the Edict of Nantes in 1598, and granted wide-ranging freedom of religion to the Huguenots.
ＤThe following text is an extract from John Reed's book Ten Days That Shook the World.
The Petrograd Soviet was in full swing, thronged with armed men, Trotsky reporting:
'From Moscow, bad news. The Kremlin is in the hands of the yunkers, and the workers have only a few arms. The result depends on Petrograd.
At the front, the decrees on Peace and Land are provoking great enthusiasm. Kerensky is flooding the trenches with tales of Petrograd burning and bloody, of women and children massacred by the (9). But no one believes him.
The cruisers including Avrora are anchored in the Neva, their guns trained on the approaches to the city....'
'Why aren't you out there with the Red Guards?' shouted a rough voice.
'I'm going now!' answered Trotsky, and left the platform.
Question 9
From ①~④ below, choose the correct word or phrase that should be inserted into the gap marked (9) in the text.
38
①Tsarist government
②Bolsheviki
③Provisional government
④Constitutional Democratic Party
Question 10
What was the incident that "shook the world" depicted in the foregoing text?Choose the correct answer from options ①~④ below.
39
①The February (March) Revolution
②The May (June) Revolution
③The July (August) Revolution
④The October (November) Revolution
Question 11
At that time, Russia was in the middle of a war that had been going on for some years.From ①~④ below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes that war.
40
①Tolstoy wrote a very long historical novel on the subject of this war.
②Russia fought against the Ottoman Empire, which was on the side of the Allies.
③Russia concluded an alliance with Austria-Hungary.
④Russia concluded the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk to make peace with the Entente Powers.
